articles.headline: Trump Signs Bill Reopening Government for 3 Weeks in Surprise Retreat From Wall
articles.snippet: The plan will fund the government until Feb. 15 while Republicans and Democrats negotiate over border security. The plan includes none of the money for the border wall that the president had demanded.
articles.abstract: The plan will fund the government until Feb. 15 while Republicans and Democrats negotiate over border security. The plan includes none of the money for the border wall that the president had demanded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump agreed on Friday to reopen the federal government for three weeks while negotiations continued over how to secure the nation’s southwestern border, backing down after a monthlong standoff failed to force Democrats to give him billions of dollars for his long-promised wall.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Roger Stone’s Dirty Tricks Put Him Where He’s Always Wanted to Be: Center Stage
articles.snippet: “I have always said, the only thing worse than being talked about is not being talked about,” Mr. Stone said after he was indicted in the special counsel investigation.
articles.abstract: “I have always said, the only thing worse than being talked about is not being talked about,” Mr. Stone said after he was indicted in the special counsel investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two years, Roger J. Stone Jr. has seemed like the most obvious suspect in an old-fashioned mystery, the self-described dirty trickster taunting the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, to come at him while selling T-shirts proclaiming his innocence.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How Tariffs Stained the Washing Machine Market
articles.snippet: A year after the Trump administration tried to help American manufacturers of laundry equipment, prices are up, sales have fallen and stock prices are down.
articles.abstract: A year after the Trump administration tried to help American manufacturers of laundry equipment, prices are up, sales have fallen and stock prices are down.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may not have appreciated it at the time — golden eras have a habit of coming and going like that — but a five-year stretch that started in 2013 was a pretty great time to buy a washing machine.

articles.headline: The Hidden Automation Agenda of the Davos Elite
articles.snippet: In public, executives wring their hands over automation’s negative consequences for workers. In private, they talk about how they are racing to automate.
articles.abstract: In public, executives wring their hands over automation’s negative consequences for workers. In private, they talk about how they are racing to automate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — They’ll never admit it in public, but many of your bosses want machines to replace you as soon as possible.

articles.headline: Within Venezuelan Military Ranks, a Struggle Over What Leader to Back
articles.snippet: The leadership publicly swore allegiance to the nation’s president, Nicolás Maduro, but interviews show a more complicated, ongoing conflict in the rank and file.
articles.abstract: The leadership publicly swore allegiance to the nation’s president, Nicolás Maduro, but interviews show a more complicated, ongoing conflict in the rank and file.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Venezuelans took to the streets this week to demand a return to democracy, they chose a date with deep historic significance: Jan. 23, the day a dictatorship collapsed in the face of surging protests more than 60 years ago.

articles.headline: For a President Consumed With Winning, a Stinging Defeat
articles.snippet: President Trump learns the hard way about the political danger of shutdowns and his limits in an era of divided power.
articles.abstract: President Trump learns the hard way about the political danger of shutdowns and his limits in an era of divided power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump famously declared that in his administration the nation would become tired of all the winning. So on Friday he tried a little losing.

articles.headline: Why Are Young People Pretending to Love Work?
articles.snippet: I saw the greatest minds of my generation log 18-hour days — and then boast about #hustle on Instagram. When did performative workaholism become a lifestyle?
articles.abstract: I saw the greatest minds of my generation log 18-hour days — and then boast about #hustle on Instagram. When did performative workaholism become a lifestyle?
articles.lead_paragraph: Never once at the start of my workweek — not in my morning coffee shop line; not in my crowded subway commute; not as I begin my bottomless inbox slog — have I paused, looked to the heavens and whispered: #ThankGodIt’sMonday.

articles.headline: A Bruised Trump Faces Uncertain 2020 Prospects. His Team Fears a Primary Fight.
articles.snippet: With his approval rating sinking, and foes within the party wooing potential Republican challengers, aides to the president are working to shore up his support.
articles.abstract: With his approval rating sinking, and foes within the party wooing potential Republican challengers, aides to the president are working to shore up his support.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s defeat in his border-wall standoff with Congress has clouded his already perilous path to a second term in 2020, undercutting Mr. Trump’s cherished image as a forceful leader and deft negotiator, and emboldening alike his Democratic challengers and Republican dissenters who hope to block his re-election.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How the Shutdown Reordered American Life
articles.snippet: People accustomed to paychecks were forced to moonlight, visit food pantries and apply for unemployment benefits. A stable job suddenly felt high risk.
articles.abstract: People accustomed to paychecks were forced to moonlight, visit food pantries and apply for unemployment benefits. A stable job suddenly felt high risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On Day 1 of what would become the longest government shutdown in the country’s history, Mary Kelly had a typically American view of the situation: She was optimistic. As an employee of the Internal Revenue Service, she had been through shutdowns before. This one would not last long, she figured.

articles.headline: On Venezuela, Rubio Assumes U.S. Role of Ouster in Chief
articles.snippet: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, has become a chief policy architect for the United States in a daring and risky campaign to dislodge Venezuela’s autocratic leader from power.
articles.abstract: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, has become a chief policy architect for the United States in a daring and risky campaign to dislodge Venezuela’s autocratic leader from power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His hand chopping in the air, his voice stern and stalwart, he declared that it was time for the regional despot to go and warned of the consequences if he did not. With a commander in chief’s resolve, he vowed that the United States would do whatever it took to protect its own diplomats on the ground.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Edward Wong

articles.headline: U.S. and Taliban Edge Toward Deal to End America’s Longest War
articles.snippet: Six days of peace talks that wrapped up Saturday were the most serious negotiations yet to make way for an American troop withdrawal and an end to the 17-year war.
articles.abstract: Six days of peace talks that wrapped up Saturday were the most serious negotiations yet to make way for an American troop withdrawal and an end to the 17-year war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States and the Taliban are closing in on a deal to end America’s longest war after six days of some of the most serious Afghan peace negotiations to date wrapped up on Saturday.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: In 5G Race With China, U.S. Pushes Allies to Fight Huawei
articles.snippet: With 5G networks about to remake the internet, the Trump administration fears decisions made in the next six months on China’s role will resonate for decades.
articles.abstract: With 5G networks about to remake the internet, the Trump administration fears decisions made in the next six months on China’s role will resonate for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeremy Hunt, the British foreign minister, arrived in Washington last week for a whirlwind of meetings facing a critical question: Should Britain risk its relationship with Beijing and agree to the Trump administration’s request to ban Huawei, China’s leading telecommunications producer, from building its next-generation computer and phone networks?
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes, Raymond Zhong and Marc Santora

articles.headline: The Tabloid Myths of Jennifer Aniston and Donald Trump
articles.snippet: She wants to reunite with Brad Pitt and have a baby. He’s a self-made guy from the streets. Or so certain segments of the media would have you believe.
articles.abstract: She wants to reunite with Brad Pitt and have a baby. He’s a self-made guy from the streets. Or so certain segments of the media would have you believe.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a depressing news cycle, the cover of In Touch Weekly’s Jan. 21 issue was a beautiful sight.

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren’s 2020 Strategy: Stand Out by ‘Nerding Out’
articles.snippet: Ms. Warren’s passion for policy minutiae has become her way of distinguishing herself in a large Democratic field. But some voters say she risks being seen as out of touch and too intellectual.
articles.abstract: Ms. Warren’s passion for policy minutiae has become her way of distinguishing herself in a large Democratic field. But some voters say she risks being seen as out of touch and too intellectual.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — The gym was hot. The lights malfunctioned. But the audience of nearly 1,000 people was engrossed as Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat and presidential hopeful, did what she does best: “nerd out,” as she puts it.

articles.headline: Elite Law Firm’s All-White Partner Class Stirs Debate on Diversity
articles.snippet: Paul, Weiss is more diverse at its top ranks than most of its peers. But its recent promotions underscored how far big firms have to go to elevate women and people of color.
articles.abstract: Paul, Weiss is more diverse at its top ranks than most of its peers. But its recent promotions underscored how far big firms have to go to elevate women and people of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: The post appeared on LinkedIn in early December: Paul, Weiss, one of the country’s most prominent and profitable law firms, said it was “pleased to announce” its new partner class.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and John Eligon

articles.headline: Your 2019 Tax Refund Might Be Higher, Lower or Later Than Usual
articles.snippet: It’s unclear how the Trump tax law will affect refunds in what has been a clockwork injection of cash into the economy. The shutdown’s effects are murkier still.
articles.abstract: It’s unclear how the Trump tax law will affect refunds in what has been a clockwork injection of cash into the economy. The shutdown’s effects are murkier still.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have come to count on tax refunds to fuel their spending in the waning days of winter. But as income tax filing season opens on Monday, a sweeping tax code overhaul and the lingering effects of a government shutdown could squeeze taxpayers’ refund checks and delay them, too.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: As I.P.O. Approaches, Lyft’s Chief Is Nudged Into the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Logan Green is known to be reserved, letting his second-in-command speak for their ride-sharing service. But now he’s in a race with Uber to take the companies public.
articles.abstract: Logan Green is known to be reserved, letting his second-in-command speak for their ride-sharing service. But now he’s in a race with Uber to take the companies public.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Logan Green, chief executive of the ride-hailing service Lyft, was asked which tech leaders he admired, he pointed to three men who had built their companies ruthlessly: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Jeff Bezos.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: As Government Reopens, the New Congress Tries to Begin Again
articles.snippet: The end of the shutdown means that the agendas of both chambers of Congress, overshadowed for weeks by the struggle to reopen government, will get a restart.
articles.abstract: The end of the shutdown means that the agendas of both chambers of Congress, overshadowed for weeks by the struggle to reopen government, will get a restart.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the government shutdown over for now, the 116th Congress will hit reset this week, showcasing a Democratic agenda in the House that was overshadowed by the struggle to reopen the government and furnishing both chambers with early opportunities to test whether divided government can produce results.

articles.headline: Afghan Women Fear Peace With Taliban May Mean War on Them
articles.snippet: The idea of an American troop withdrawal fills Afghan women with dread, as they see Westerners as their only protectors not just from the Taliban, but also the “Taliban mentality” among other men.
articles.abstract: The idea of an American troop withdrawal fills Afghan women with dread, as they see Westerners as their only protectors not just from the Taliban, but also the “Taliban mentality” among other men.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Rahima Jami heard that the Americans and the Taliban were close to a peace deal, she thought about her feet.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland, Fatima Faizi and Fahim Abed

articles.headline: As 2020 Looms, the News Media Looks Forward, and Back
articles.snippet: Informed by the unexpected outcome of 2016, will journalists be better equipped to report on a race this time around?
articles.abstract: Informed by the unexpected outcome of 2016, will journalists be better equipped to report on a race this time around?
articles.lead_paragraph: As Americans brace for the next presidential campaign — already underway and showing on a screen near you — press pundits are worried about the news media’s readiness for the challenge ahead.

articles.headline: A Tiny Screw Shows Why iPhones Won’t Be ‘Assembled in U.S.A.’
articles.snippet: Apple decided several years ago to produce a high-end Mac in Texas. The problems that surfaced illustrate the challenges of domestic manufacturing.
articles.abstract: Apple decided several years ago to produce a high-end Mac in Texas. The problems that surfaced illustrate the challenges of domestic manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Despite a trade war between the United States and China and past admonishments from President Trump “to start building their damn computers and things in this country,” Apple is unlikely to bring its manufacturing closer to home.

articles.headline: U.S. and Taliban Agree in Principle to Peace Framework, Envoy Says
articles.snippet: The U.S. negotiator, Zalmay Khalilzad, says that finalizing a deal would hinge on a cease-fire and Taliban talks with Afghans, which they are discussing now.
articles.abstract: The U.S. negotiator, Zalmay Khalilzad, says that finalizing a deal would hinge on a cease-fire and Taliban talks with Afghans, which they are discussing now.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and Taliban officials have agreed in principle to the framework of a deal in which the insurgents would guarantee Afghan territory is never used by terrorists, which could lead to a full pullout of American troops in return for larger concessions from the Taliban, the chief United States negotiator said on Monday.
